awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: WoU-MMA: Revealing the Fate of Heavy Nuclei in Stellar Explosions and Pathways to Cosmic Rays
awd_abstract_narration:
Cosmic rays are sub-atomic particles that reach the earth from outer space.  Some cosmic rays are the highest energy particles ever detected by humans, far exceeding the energies produced in the largest particle accelerator experiments.  The origin of these ultra-high energy cosmic rays and the distribution of their masses remains a mystery.  A science collaboration between Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University and Pennsylvania State University will carry out a research program designed to further knowledge of the origins of ultra-high energy cosmic rays (UHECR) by establishing detailed connections to massive stars, and to two different, but related types of exploding stars: supernovae and gamma-ray bursts. The research will focus on understanding the distribution of masses of ultra-high energy cosmic rays, which will be used to address long-standing challenges in the quest for unraveling the origins of cosmic rays. The work will benefit from ongoing discoveries of how supernovae explosions are driven, and the development of a new multi-messenger astronomy that combines traditional observations of light with observations of cosmic rays and other particles from space. The research is interdisciplinary, requiring detailed astrophysical numerical models, applications of nuclear physics, and considerations of sub-atomic particle acceleration and interactions.  Finally, the project includes an active outreach program aimed at local high schools. The centerpiece is the integration of a smartphone app "Crayfis" that detects UHECR by a network of smartphone CCDs triggering on the particles called muons created by the cosmic-rays. The app will be used as a catalyst to share excitement in astrophysics and discovery and it will leverage the existing Virginia Tech QuarkNet infrastructure to work with high school teachers, thereby reaching out to a large and broad range of students.

A comprehensive numerical study, starting from the origins of nuclei in jets to their pathways to ultra-high energy cosmic rays, will be performed. These studies will deliver predictions for the mass compositions of ultra-high energy cosmic rays and allow quantitative comparisons with ultra-high energy cosmic-ray and multi-messenger observables.  The main tasks of the proposal are: (i) to establish detailed predictions for the nuclear mass compositions of engine-driven supernovae and gamma-ray burst jets; (ii) to quantify the modification to such nuclear abundances during jet propagation, cosmic-ray acceleration in dissipation regions, and cosmic-ray propagation in intergalactic space; (iii) to make signal predictions for cosmic ray and multi-messenger observables; and (iv) to perform quantitative comparisons with data. Together, these tasks will deliver a quantitative assessment of engine-driven supernovae and gamma-ray bursts as sources of ultra-high energy cosmic ray nuclei.  This project advances the goals of the NSF Windows on the Universe Big Idea.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The origins of ultrahigh-energy cosmic rays (UHECRs) and high-energy neutrinos are big enigmas in astroparticle physics. We explored connections between the mysterious nuclear composition of the UHECRs and the explosions of massive stars at the end of their lives. Gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) and engine-driven supernovae were of particular interest.    

 
We performed comprehensive studies on the synthesis and fate of heavy element nuclei in outflows (jets and winds) launched from a rapidly-rotating magnetar as the central engine. We showed that heavy nuclei can be synthesized especially in Poynting-flux dominated outflows or low-luminosity jets, although these outflows generally fail to achieve the production of elements heavier than lanthanides. UHECR acceleration and survival of the heavy nuclei are also possible for low-luminosity outflows. We also investigated high-energy neutrino emission from magnetized jets, and showed that the signals from successful jets are unlikely to be detected in IceCube, consistent with non-detection of GRB neutrinos.


We investigated observational signatures of supernovae supported by magnetar winds. Neutrons are naturally loaded into the winds or nebulae especially if synthesized nuclei are disintegrated via magnetic dissipation. We revealed spectra and light curves of resulting quasi-thermal neutrino emission in the GeV range. We also investigated the scenario that UHECRs are accelerated in magnetar winds, and discussed the detectability of ultrahigh-energy neutrinos, which may originate from the decay of charm hadrons. Rapidly-rotating magnetars are thought to be among the promising central engines that can power super-luminous supernovae. We studied radio and gamma-ray signatures of the nebulae powered by magnetar winds, and obtained constraints on the magnetar-supported supernova model. We also explored the possibility that bumps observed in optical light curves of some super-luminous supernovae are caused by variations of the thermal energy injection from the spin down. 


To obtain general implications of UHECR data, we derived energy generation rate densities of UHECRs for different compositions. Furthermore, considering the IceCube neutrino data, we obtained generic parameter space required for the unified origin of UHECRs and high-energy neutrinos, and found that low-luminosity GRBs and engine-driven supernovae can satisfy the requirements. We also developed a numerical code, AMES, to treat the detailed propagation of UHECR nuclei interacting with arbitrary radiation fields, considering photodisintegration, photohadronic interactions, and nuclear cascades.  


We explored high-energy signatures of GRBs. In this context, we developed the AMES module to numerically calculate spectra and light curves of GRB afterglows from radio to gamma-ray bands, by which we modeled several TeV-detected GRBs, which include GRB 190114C, GRB 168021B, GRB 190829A, and GRB 221009A that is the brightest gamma-ray burst ever recorded. In particular, we showed that the highest-energy gamma-ray data of GRB 221009A may be explained by synchrotron emission from UHECRs.


The research involved a postdoctoral researcher and several students, and thereby provided them with training. In collaboration with Virginia Tech, the postdoc and two graduate students jointly worked and their efficient collaborations were essential for accomplishing the research.
